stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on an oil rig level, focusing on implementing a complex easter egg for a 'Builder Koopa' that involved texture manipulation and custom animations from Zeina. He also spent significant time designing, modeling, and rigging the level's 'Wiggler Overseer' character, collaborating with Biobak on its core design. The stream featured deep dives into technical problem-solving, design philosophy, and team dynamics.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is using smaller-scale game releases like 'Only Up 64' as public betas to gather playtest data and refine the core RTYI engine, particularly its physics and camera systems, before the main game's release.
development_findings.quote: Only up 64 was really really useful playtest data and I'm gonna use the playtest data to prove RTYI. We should make like one or two more hacks on the RTYI engine before RTYI is released just to like get everything a little bit improved.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has adopted more structured coding practices, such as using defines instead of magic numbers and adding comments, a change inspired by professional development workflows from other projects.
development_findings.quote: I took notes from how we work in years for breakfast and I decided I will make all the magic numbers into defines in this file and I even added comic comments that follow some sort of code guidelines.

development_findings.summary: To implement the 'dirty cement' easter egg, Kaze developed a performant solution to check the texture state by sampling a small subset of pixels at a specific interval, avoiding the need to iterate through all 16,384 pixels on every frame.
development_findings.quote: Doesn't this look perfect? Like we just cut computation costs into like not even fucking, like basically a 15th.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is critical of the SM64 PC port (SM64EX), stating that its graphics rendering is a simulation, not a true emulation, which causes many of his custom visual effects to break. This reinforces his commitment to N64 compatibility.
development_findings.quote: The thing about the PC port is that the graphics emulator they have built into that doesn't actually emulate the graphics very well... It only simulates the graphics instead of emulating it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to redesign the level warp transition to be seamless. Instead of a hard cut, Mario's state and inputs will be preserved during the transition, which he believes will look much better at 60 FPS.
development_findings.quote: I'm gonna completely change the warps. So what I'm gonna do is that the inputs are just gonna be held... Mario's normal action are just gonna continue while the warp is happening. So it won't look weird at all because of 60fps.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejected using the high-poly SM64DS Wiggler model, recalling a past trend in the hacking community where creators bragged about high polygon counts, which he views as a sign of inefficiency rather than quality.
development_findings.quote: There was a weird time in Mars 64 hacking where people were proud of how many polygons the level set... that's like people who buy expensive clothing.

development_findings.summary: The level's main antagonist is a Wiggler overseer who becomes progressively angrier as the player disrupts his workers, culminating in him having a breakdown and leaving the level entirely.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes in designing for a specific audience, acknowledging that a large portion of the romhacking community consists of experienced players. He understands that this may alienate casual players but will result in positive feedback from the core community.
context_findings.quote: If you make your hacks in a way that only super experienced players enjoy it, you will still get almost entirely positive reviews. Exactly. You have to know your target audience.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels that players often misattribute engine quirks in his hack as bugs, when in reality they are faithful reproductions of the original Mario 64's behavior that players have forgotten over time.
context_findings.quote: There's definitely a rose tinting with vanilla Mario 64 collision. A lot of people were looking at some of the oddities in the collision in RTYI and it was just like, yeah, this is a vanilla thing. That's just how Mario 64 works, bro.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has deliberately moved his streaming from Twitch to YouTube due to his frustration with Twitch's aggressive ad policy, which he feels has made the platform unusable.
context_findings.quote: I switched off twitch. Twitch is just so many ads that I just don't like it anymore. I don't enjoy watching twitch streams anymore so I decided it is time to leave.

context_findings.summary: He streams on his secondary YouTube channel to maintain a focused community and chat that is dedicated to the project, rather than attracting a large, general audience.
context_findings.quote: I kind of want to filter this chat to only be the people that actually care about the project. I don't want just a thousand randoms coming in here and talking about random stuff.

context_findings.summary: Kaze spent significant time contemplating paying for Twitter Blue to access ad revenue, weighing the potential income against the platform's requirements and the social cost of having a blue checkmark, revealing a pragmatic and entrepreneurial mindset.
context_findings.quote: You guys have no idea the shit I would do for $5 a month on Twitter ad revenue.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a disdain for ostentatious displays of wealth or cost, relating it to an old trend in the hacking community where creators would brag about high polygon counts as a mark of quality, which he views as a sign of inefficiency.
context_findings.quote: Bragging about how much the stuff you have costs is so funny to me. It's like, okay, all you did was prove that you just managed to get a bad deal.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided direct, critical feedback on a broken glass texture Kaze had made, prompting a discussion and changes.
biobak.quote: This is just not how glass breaks. This is not acceptable. What's wrong with it?

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested the Wiggler overseer should be standing up, similar to its appearance in Mario Tennis. This idea was immediately adopted by Kaze and became the core design direction for the character's posture.
biobak.quote: Google Wiggler standing up, first image result. Oh, oh. Yes, exactly that.

badub.summary: Kaze played a new version of a level's OST, presumably by Badub, noting that it was an improvement and contained samples from the Super Smash Bros. Melee menu, indicating Badub's influences and iterative process.
badub.quote: Dude this is melee. You hear that? That was the melee menu. I think he did use the menu sound yes.

zeina.summary: Kaze tasked Zeina with creating a unique sobbing animation for the Builder Koopa as part of a new easter egg, demonstrating their collaborative workflow where Kaze provides direction for a specific gameplay need.
zeina.quote: Did you hear the plans Zeina? What? So basically you ruin his [cement]... But if you like basically make almost the entire area black, he's just gonna start crying and he's gonna have a new text. So you should give him a sobbing animation for that. Can you do that real quick?

zeina.summary: Zeina actively participates in the creative process, suggesting her own ideas for animations (a stomping tantrum) before aligning with Kaze's specific vision (a crying animation) for the character.
zeina.quote: Wait, can I give him a stomping tantrum? Well, I mean, the easter egg is that he's saying, 'do you want to make me cry?' Ah, I see.

zeina.summary: Zeina created and delivered multiple animation takes for the Koopa, including a version with a stomp and a revised version with just a looping cry, which Kaze then implemented.
zeina.quote: Alright, I got rid of the stomp, I just have a looping cry.

key_stories.title: The Crying Koopa Easter Egg
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted a Builder Koopa to have a breakdown if the player completely ruined his wet cement. Facing a performance bottleneck, he designed a clever texture-sampling algorithm to approximate the damage. He then collaborated with Zeina to create a custom crying animation, resulting in a unique, performance-friendly easter egg.
key_stories.challenge: How to create a hidden, rewarding easter egg for a minor NPC (a Builder Koopa) without causing significant performance issues on the N64.
key_stories.process: Kaze conceived the idea of the Koopa reacting to his cement being ruined. To avoid iterating over the entire texture, he devised a sampling algorithm that checks pixels at a specific interval (176) to approximate the total 'dirtiness'. He then directed Zeina to create a custom sobbing animation, provided feedback, and integrated it with a new dialogue trigger.
key_stories.outcome: A fully implemented easter egg where ruining ~95% of the cement triggers a special crying animation and dialogue. The feature is performant, visually clear, and adds a humorous and interactive secret to the level.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't want to iterate 16,384 elements here. How about to approximate this we just take 16 pixels every... that wouldn't work either. I need something that randomly picks a few pixels on the screen.

key_stories.title: Designing the Wiggler Overseer
key_stories.summary: The Wiggler overseer character lacked presence. After rejecting existing models, Kaze and the team brainstormed. Biobak suggested a standing pose from Mario Tennis, which sparked a complete redesign. Kaze then began modifying the character model to stand upright and have arms, giving it a more commanding and fitting appearance.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed to design the level's main NPC, a Wiggler 'Overseer', but his default appearance didn't fit the role and a simple model looked uninspired.
key_stories.process: Kaze initially struggled with the Wiggler model, rejecting a high-poly version from SM64DS. The team discussed how to make him look like a manager. Biobak suggested the standing pose from Mario Tennis, which Kaze immediately embraced. This led to Kaze modifying the model in Blender to add arms and remove the helmets from the body segments to better fit the new pose.
key_stories.outcome: The team settled on a new design direction: a Wiggler standing upright on its last two segments, with its front segments replaced by arms. This required significant model and rig adjustments but created a more authoritative and unique character.
key_stories.key_quote: Google Wiggler standing up, first image result. Oh, oh. Yes, exactly that.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that he plans to release 'one or two more hacks on the RTYI engine' before the final game to gather 'playtest data' and make improvements, citing lessons learned from 'Only Up 64'.
questions: What is the overall strategy behind releasing these smaller 'test' hacks before the main project?
What specific systems in the RTYI engine do you feel need the most refinement through this public testing?
Can you give a concrete example of a piece of feedback from 'Only Up 64' that led to a direct change in RTYI's physics or camera?

open_questions.context: Kaze revealed that there is at least one major secret in his previous hack, 'Lost Impact,' that the community has not yet found. He specified it has to do with a boss fight.
questions: Without spoiling it, what can you tell us about the nature of this unfound secret in Lost Impact?
Why do you think it has remained hidden for so long?
What does this say about your philosophy on designing secrets for only the most dedicated players?

open_questions.context: The stream showed a dynamic where Kaze directs Zeina's animation work and collaborates on design with Biobak. They clearly have an effective workflow.
questions: Can you walk us through the typical collaborative process for a new character or feature, from concept to implementation?
How are creative disagreements resolved within the team?
How does your personal relationship as a married couple affect your professional collaboration on the game?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he has started using defines for magic numbers and adding comments, a practice he picked up from other projects. This seems like a shift in his development style.
questions: What prompted this change towards writing more readable and maintainable code?
Was there a specific problem or moment in a past project that made you realize the limitations of your old 'uncommented' style?
How has this new approach affected your collaboration with others or the overall development speed?

open_questions.context: Kaze described the Wiggler Overseer's arc as getting progressively angrier until he 'just loses it' and disappears. This sounds like a unique narrative beat.
questions: What does it look like when the Wiggler 'loses it'? Can you describe the final cutscene or animation?
What was the narrative inspiration for having a character essentially have a workplace meltdown in a Mario game?
What gameplay purpose does his disappearance serve for the player?

open_questions.context: Kaze played a new version of a level's music and pointed out a sample from Super Smash Bros. Melee, crediting it as an improvement from the first version.
questions: What is the feedback loop like between you and Badub for the game's music?
How do you communicate the desired 'feel' of a level to him?
How do ideas for using specific samples, like the Melee menu sound, come about in your discussions?
